cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts referring to the dead person as the subject of ancient Egyptian burial, mummification, and afterlife practices, including both the individual and their preserved body.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Dead individual in ancient Egyptian burial practices... body of the dead person intended to be preserved and protected within the pyramid or tomb.

members.entity_description: Dead individual in ancient Egyptian burial practices, whose body is mummified, buried with goods and texts, and believed to journey through the afterlife.
The physical body of the dead person intended to be preserved and protected within the pyramid or tomb in ancient Egyptian burial practices.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated concepts involved in the Ancient Egyptian mummification practice, including the core embalming process, treatment of internal organs, desiccation using salt, and wrapping with linen bandages.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Egyptian body-preservation burial practice involving organ removal, drying out the body with salt, and wrapping it in linen bandages.

members.entity_description: Ancient Egyptian burial and embalming process of preserving a corpse to prevent decay and prepare it for the afterlife, involving body preservation through organ removal, desiccation, and wrapping.
Soft organs inside the body that were removed during mummification.
Use of salt to dry out a corpse as part of mummification.
Strips of linen cloth used to wrap the mummified body.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated beliefs, states, locations, and processes that constitute the ancient Egyptian conception of the afterlife, including the post-death realm, the soul’s journey, desired conditions, and the divine domain of the gods.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: All entities describe aspects of the ancient Egyptian afterlife: its realm, soul’s journey, goals like safe passage and eternal existence, and provisions for comfort and sustenance.

members.entity_description: The ancient Egyptian religious conception of the afterlife, encompassing the post-death realm, the journey of the soul, associated deities, and the rituals and practices intended to ensure safe passage and eternal life.
Divine domain in ancient Egyptian belief where the gods dwell and where the deceased sought to exist eternally after successfully navigating the afterlife.
Concept of pyramids functioning as an entry point from the living world to the afterlife.
State of ease and well-being intended for the deceased through burial items.
Provision of nourishment to the deceased through items buried with them.
Spiritual component of a person believed to be reunited with the body in the afterlife.
Spiritual voyage the deceased was believed to undertake after death.
Believed post-death existence for which Egyptians prepared the deceased with tombs and grave goods.
Desired successful journey of the deceased from death to the afterlife.

members.entity_name: eternal existence in the realm of the gods
members.entity_description: Ongoing, unending life of the deceased among the gods.

cluster_classes.class_description: Interrelated practices and value systems in ancient Egypt concerning death, burial, and honoring the dead, encompassing both ritual procedures and underlying moral-religious attitudes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Both entities concern how ancient Egyptians buried and honored the dead, including rituals and cultural values of reverence.

members.entity_description: The complex customs, rituals, and methods used in ancient Egypt to prepare and inter the dead, involving priests, embalmers, and other specialists to ensure a proper transition to the afterlife and to honor the deceased.

members.entity_name: reverence for the deceased in ancient Egypt
members.entity_description: The cultural and moral value in ancient Egyptian society of showing honor, respect, and veneration to the dead, often expressed through funerary rites, memorial practices, and beliefs about the afterlife.

remarks: This class has been structurally split into more specific subclasses; consider deprecating or hiding it from primary use once downstream references are updated.

cluster_classes.class_description: Roles comprising the professional participants in ancient Egyptian burial practices, including religious officiants, body preparers, and other specialized contributors.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The process of burial...required the expertise of priests, embalmers, and other skilled individuals.

members.entity_description: Religious specialists involved in performing and overseeing ancient Egyptian burial rituals.
Specialists responsible for preparing and preserving bodies during ancient Egyptian burials.
Additional unnamed specialists contributing expertise to the ancient Egyptian burial process.

splits.name: Ancient Egyptian Burial Practices
splits.description: The complex customs, rituals, and methods used in ancient Egypt to prepare and inter the dead, including preparation of the body, tomb arrangements, and associated rites to ensure a proper transition to the afterlife.

splits.name: Reverence for the Deceased in Ancient Egypt
splits.description: The cultural and moral value in ancient Egyptian society of showing honor, respect, and veneration to the dead, expressed through funerary rites, memorial practices, and beliefs about the afterlife.

args.justification: ClsC_cbdd742c mixes a concrete process ('ancient Egyptian burial practices') with an abstract moral value ('reverence for the deceased'); splitting yields cleaner, single-focus classes for practices vs values.

args.new_description: Concepts referring to the dead individual as the subject of ancient Egyptian burial, mummification, and afterlife practices, including both the person and their preserved body.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Renaming clarifies that this class covers the deceased as the focal subject of funerary treatment, and assigning a shared Class_Group connects it to the broader ancient Egyptian funerary schema.

args.new_description: Interrelated practices involved in ancient Egyptian mummification, including the embalming process, treatment and removal of internal organs, desiccation using salts, and wrapping with linen bandages.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Updated name and description emphasize practical, ritual actions and aligning the Class_Group situates mummification within the overall funerary religion and culture domain.

args.new_name: Ancient Egyptian Afterlife Beliefs and Concepts
args.new_description: Beliefs, states, locations, and processes that constitute the ancient Egyptian conception of the afterlife, including the post-death realm, the soul's journey, desired conditions such as comfort and sustenance, and eternal existence among the gods.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Minor renaming and shared Class_Group clarify that this class focuses on the belief and conceptual side of the same funerary religious system as the other classes.

args.new_description: Former umbrella class for both burial practices and reverence values in ancient Egyptian funerary culture; its members have been split into more specific classes.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.remark: This class has been structurally split into more specific subclasses; consider deprecating or hiding it from primary use once downstream references are updated.
args.justification: After splitting ClsC_cbdd742c into focused practice and value classes, updating its metadata and Class_Group clarifies its superseded/container status for maintainers.

args.new_description: The complex customs, rituals, and methods used in ancient Egypt to prepare and inter the dead, encompassing body preparation, tomb arrangements, offerings, and associated rites to ensure a proper transition to the afterlife.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Assigning an explicit Class_Group and refining the name/description position this split-out class as the general umbrella for burial procedures within the funerary system.

args.new_name: Reverence for the Deceased in Ancient Egypt
args.new_description: The cultural and moral value in ancient Egyptian society of honoring, respecting, and venerating the dead, expressed through funerary rites, memorialization, and beliefs about the afterlife.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Clarifying this split-out class as a cultural value and assigning the shared Class_Group highlights its role as the normative/ideological dimension of the funerary system.

args.new_description: Occupational roles comprising the professional participants in ancient Egyptian burial practices, including priests, embalmers, and other specialized contributors involved in funerary rituals and body preparation.
args.new_class_group: Ancient Egyptian Funerary Religion and Culture
args.justification: Assigning the shared Class_Group and slightly expanding the description clearly link these roles to the common funerary religion and culture context.
